Policy:

Existing enforcement procedures
should be modified to immediately
correct damage and prevent further
destruction caused by illegal fill.

Goal:

The City should receive
equitable reimbursement for
local revenues lost to tax exempt
uses in the port.

Current procedure against illegal fill is
directed more to pursuing the violater
rather than correcting and preventing fur-
ther damage to the harbor’s water quality.

There have been a number of projects
around the harbor which have started with-
out installing approved erosion and sedi-
ment control devices. This has resulted in
sediment being washed into the harbor.
Although violation notices have been
issued, lengthy court battles, inadequate
enforcement staff, disputes over the respon-
sibility of constructing the control devices,
etc. have caused long delays in the resolu-
tion of the violation. During this period
there is little or no action taken to control
the erosion problem. This allows sediment
to continue to wash into storm drains,
streams and.the harbor and only increases
the negative impact of the project to the
water body, adjacent properties and esca-
lates the cost of correcting the problem.

Regulations should be developed by
the State which not only identifies the viola-
tion but also requires action to prevent any
further damage which might occur during
the enforcement procedures.

Because the City has a limited tax base
it has pursued an economic development
program to retain and attract industry which
maximizes, in terms of jobs and taxes, the
use of the industrial land adjacent to the
harbor. Of the approximately 6,100 acres of
industrial land around the harbor over 1,300
acres are exempt from property taxes
because of ownership by the State (Mary-
land Port Administration) and the railroads.
If just the 1,300 acres of land owned by the
railroads and MPA were assessed and taxed
at the same rate as other private industrial
land, over $2,300,000 in property taxes
would be generated each year. Meanwhile,
the City must incur the cost of services to
these facilities: police and fire protection,
roads, etc. An example of this can be found
in the operation of the harbor’s fire boats.
The City purchases, maintains and operates
fire boats which must protect ships in the
harbor and mgrine terminals. While it costs
the City approximately $3.1 million each
year to provide this service to the port it
received only $1.8 million from the state in
1982 towards covering that cost.

In addition to direct outlays that the
City must assume there are also indirect
loses. In several instances the MPA leases its
terminals to private operators. These facili-
ties function as private terminals although
they enjoy the unique advantage of paying
either limited or no taxes to the local juris-
diction. Only a small payment-in-lieu of
taxes, just over $100,000 from terminal oper-
ations, is passed on annually to the City
from the MPA.
